name: The Amduat
primarySources: Tomb of Thutmose I (first complete version)
attributes: Union of Ra and Osiris theology
summary: The Amduat (Book of What is in the Duat) is the oldest and most complete guide to the Egyptian underworld, detailing the sun god Ra's twelve-hour nocturnal journey through the realm of the dead and his triumphant rebirth at dawn.
keyPassages: First Hour: Entry into the western horizon, realm of the blessed dead
Fifth Hour: The cavern of Sokar, deepest and most dangerous region
Sixth Hour: Ra encounters his own corpse (union with Osiris)
Seventh Hour: Battle with Apophis, the chaos serpent
Twelfth Hour: Rebirth through the body of Nut, emergence as Khepri
historicalContext: The Amduat first appeared in complete form in the tomb of Thutmose I during the 18th Dynasty (c. 1493 BCE), representing the culmination of earlier solar theology and underworld beliefs. Initially reserved for royal burials, it gradually became available to high officials. The text reflects the New Kingdom synthesis of solar (Ra) and chthonic (Osiris) religious traditions, showing the dead king accompanying and becoming one with the regenerating sun.
structure: Twelve chapters (hours) depicting the sun god's nocturnal journey. Each hour describes a specific region of the Duat with illustrations, names of inhabitants, required spells, and dangers. The middle hours (4-8) represent the deepest underworld where transformation occurs. The text includes both 'short' and 'long' versions with varying levels of detail.
influence: Foundation of Egyptian afterlife beliefs; influenced later Jewish and Christian eschatology; template for subsequent underworld books (Book of Gates, Book of Caverns); continued use into Ptolemaic period

metadata.primaryRegion: Ancient Egypt, particularly Thebes (Valley of the Kings)

description: The Amduat, meaning 'Book of What is in the Duat (Underworld),' stands as ancient Egypt's oldest and most complete guide to the netherworld. This sacred funerary text describes the sun god Ra's twelve-hour nocturnal journey through the realm of the dead, from his entry at the western horizon to his glorious rebirth at dawn. Each hour corresponds to a distinct region of the Duat populated by gods, demons, and the blessed or damned dead. The text served dual purposes: as a map helping the deceased king navigate the underworld and unite with Ra, and as a theological statement about cosmic renewal through the nightly union of Ra (sun) and Osiris (death). The dramatic climax occurs when Ra, in the form of a ram-headed figure, traverses the body of the chaos serpent Apophis and merges with his own Osirian corpse, emerging regenerated as the scarab Khepri. First appearing in royal tombs around 1493 BCE, the Amduat became the template for all subsequent underworld literature and profoundly shaped Egyptian afterlife beliefs for over a millennium.
author: Egyptian Priesthood (Anonymous, compiled by Theban priests)
period: 1570-1069 BCE (New Kingdom), with use continuing through Ptolemaic era
language: Egyptian (Middle Egyptian in Hieroglyphic and Hieratic scripts)
alternateNames: Book of What is in the Duat

sections.origins: The Amduat emerged from earlier Pyramid Texts and Coffin Texts, systematizing scattered underworld references into a coherent narrative. Theban priests compiled the text during the early New Kingdom, drawing on solar theology from Heliopolis and Osirian beliefs from Abydos. The synthesis reflected changing royal ideology - the king no longer merely ascended to the stars but traveled with the sun through the underworld, participating in the cosmic cycle of death and rebirth.
sections.attributes: The text is structured as a guidebook with detailed illustrations (originally colored). Each hour includes: the name of the region, descriptions of its inhabitants, spells for safe passage, and warnings about dangers. The artwork shows Ra in his solar barque, accompanied by gods who help overcome obstacles. The text employs multiple theological identities for Ra - falcon-headed by day, ram-headed by night, scarab at dawn - representing different aspects of solar divinity.
sections.significance: The Amduat provided Egyptians with detailed knowledge of what awaited after death and how to achieve eternal life by joining Ra's eternal cycle. It established the theology of Ra-Osiris union that dominated New Kingdom religion - the living king as Horus, the dead king becoming both Ra and Osiris. The text also served magical purposes, with spells ensuring the sun's daily rebirth and thus the continuation of cosmic order.
sections.impact: The Amduat profoundly influenced subsequent Egyptian underworld texts and religious art. Its twelve-hour structure and underworld geography became standard. The text inspired the Book of Gates, Book of Caverns, and Book of the Earth. Its imagery filled royal tombs for centuries. Beyond Egypt, its concepts of underworld judgment, guided afterlife journey, and resurrection influenced Greek, Roman, Jewish, and ultimately Christian ideas about death and the beyond.
